CCDM 38.2.2.3.1 has been edited to add a reference to Exhibit 38.3.1-11, Sample Grand Jury Request memorandum.

CCDM 38.2.2.3.2 has been added to provide detailed guidance on the drafting of Chief Counsel’s Grand Jury Request memorandum. The highlighted sections of the memorandum include the: (1) identiﬁcation of the criminal subject(s), (2) Counsel’s recommendation, (3) executive summary, (4) standard of review, (5) facts, (6) law and analysis, (7) explanation of why the referral is necessary and appropriate, (8) legal impediments or other detracting factors, and (9) conclusion.
Edward F. Cronin Division Counsel/Associate Chief Counsel (Criminal Tax)

38.2 Review of Criminal Tax

Conferences should not be offered to taxpayers who are the subject of a grand jury investigation recommendation, nor should these taxpayers be advised of the existence of the grand jury recommendation.

When Criminal Investigation considers that a grand jury investigation is necessary and appropriate and believes that a grand jury investigation would develop further evidence establishing prosecutable Title 26 or Title 26-related violation(s), the investigating special agent prepares a report, fully exhibited, which comprehensively discusses to the extent possible:

which comprehensively discusses to the extent possible: a. Identiﬁcation of the criminal case(s) which is considered probable, inclusive of all tax returns at issue, identiﬁcation of all speciﬁc involved, and all indicia of wrongdoing that reﬂects the contemplated offenses b. The progress of the investigation to date, inclusive of all investigative steps already taken; all evidence already developed, identiﬁcation of witnesses interviewed and the testimony of such witnesses; and the status of administrative summonses issued but not complied with, including any summons enforcement proceedings involving the as well as a statement showing any civil action that is under way or templated on the subject for any year c. The reason(s) why seeking a grand jury investigation is believed to be necessary and appropriate in the circumstances. By way of illustration, and not by way of limitation, facts such as the following may indicate the administrative process cannot develop the relevant facts within a sonable time: — Lack of cooperation by important witnesses; — Efforts by the taxpayer to impede orderly investigation by of witnesses, destruction or threat of destruction of records or — The secreting of evidence; and — Severe time limitations imposed by the statute of limitations d. The potential deterrent effect of the anticipated case(s) on an area of noncompliance, together with the reason(s) for concluding the case(s) is sufficiently signiﬁcant to tax administration to warrant ring further investigation responsibility to a grand jury e. Recommendations as to testimony and documentary evidence to be sought before the grand jury together with identiﬁcation of possible witnesses from whom such testimonial and documentary evidence be obtainable f. Procedures
) Although the content and style of the memorandum must be tailored to the dividual case, it should contain the information discussed in this subsection. of (
) Criminal Subject(s). This section contains the name and address of the target(s). (
) Counsel’s Recommendation. This section contains Counsel’s as to whether the information contained in the Form
package meets required standard under IRM
) Standard of Review. This section lists the three pronged standard of review Grand Jury Requests. (
) Executive Summary. In a nutshell, summarize the target’s identity and criminal conduct that gives rise to the anticipated criminal violation(s) and year(s) involved. (
) Facts. Provide a brief description of the information presented in the Form

package, including a description of the target (age, background, education, etc.), contemplated charges (cite statutes), and years under gation. The facts section should also include the source of the non-tax charges and current status (if applicable), each target’s relative bility, target’s known current life style, tax ﬁling history and bank account information, known civil activity, and citations to and explanations of any relevant technical tax statutes. (

) Law and Analysis. Describe the proposed violations and years involved, with speciﬁc facts that support a ﬁnding that a crime has been committed. discussion should include a detailed analysis of the following factors: • List each violation, including its speciﬁc elements, and cite to recent cases from the appropriate circuit. • Apply the relevant facts cited within the Facts section to the speciﬁc elements of the violation. • Conclude whether the articulable facts standard has been satisﬁed. (

) Referral for a Grand Jury Investigation is Necessary and Appropriate. the unique facts of the investigation in light of the necessary and standard set forth in the IRM. Boilerplate and conclusory language should avoided. (
) Legal Impediments or Other Detracting Factors. List and describe the main legal impediments in the case. Case citations are preferred when legal issues. (
) Conclusion. In this section note whether the
package has established articulable facts supporting a reasonable belief the subject has committed alleged violations and if there are an signiﬁcant legal impediments. (
